subsection.title: Linearity of coordinate vectors

aside.title: Also
aside.p: These properties are of course true for coordinate vectors as column vectors, \matrixOf{\uvec{v}}{B} and \matrixOf{\uvec{w}}{B}, as well.

subsection.p:
We first encountered these properties in
and . We will record these properties formally in , but for now what is most important for our development of the concept of transition matrix is the extension of these properties to linear combinations:
\rmatrixOf{k_1 \uvec{v}_1 + k_2 \uvec{v}_2 + \dotsc + k_m \uvec{v}_m}{B} = k_1 \rmatrixOf{\uvec{v}_1}{B} + k_2 \rmatrixOf{\uvec{v}_2}{B} + \dotsc + k_m \rmatrixOf{\uvec{v}_m}{B} .

subsection.title: Converting coordinate vectors
subsection.p: In , we explored how we might convert from coordinate vectors relative to one basis to those relative to another basis.

Suppose we have a basis \basisfont{B} for some particular finite-dimensional vector space V. Every vector \uvec{w} in V can be expressed uniquely as a linear combination
\uvec{w} = k_1 \uvec{u}_1 + k_2 \uvec{u}_2 + \dotsc + k_n \uvec{u}_n,
where the \uvec{u}_j are the basis vectors in \basisfont{B} (), and the n-dimensional vector \rmatrixOf{\uvec{w}}{B} = (k_1,k_2,\dotsc,k_n) made up of the coefficients in that linear combination are precisely what we call the coordinate vector of \uvec{w} relative to basis \basisfont{B}. Now, what if we have a second basis \basisfont{B}' for V? We may have already gone to the work of computing the coordinate vectors for a number of vectors in V relative to \basisfont{B}. Can we easily convert these coordinate vectors to new ones relative to \basisfont{B}'?

As usual, it is helpful to express the pattern of in words, and you were asked to do this in . If we refer to \basisfont{B} as the old basis and \basisfont{B}' as the new basis, then the transition matrix \ucobmtrx{B}{B'} is formed as the n \times n matrix whose columns are the coordinate vectors of the old basis relative to the new basis.

statement.p: To compute a transition matrix \ucobmtrx{B}{B'}, where \basisfont{B} and \basisfont{B}' are bases of the same n-dimensional space, first calculate the coordinate vector of each vector in \basisfont{B} relative to the basis \basisfont{B}'. Then use these coordinate vectors, in order, as columns in the n \times n matrix \ucobmtrx{B}{B'}.

subsection.p:
We worked through an example of forming and using a transition matrix in , and you can also look through

subsection.title: Properities of transition matrices
subsection.p: In , we explored properties of transition matrices via the defining property \ucobmtrx{B}{B'} \matrixOf{\uvec{v}}{B} = \matrixOf{\uvec{v}}{B'} . We will state and prove each of the discovered properties in , but we briefly recount them here.

paragraphs.title: No change of basis
paragraphs.p: First, we considered the transition matrix for the case where the new basis is the same as the old. In this case, we want to convert each coordinate vector \matrixOf{\uvec{w}}{B} to the coordinate vector \matrixOf{\uvec{w}}{B'}. That is, we want the conversion to have no effect at all. We already know a matrix that has no effect when it is multiplied against other matrices: the identity matrix. So we expect \ucobmtrx{B}{B} = I.

paragraphs.title: Chains of basis changes
paragraphs.p: Next, we considered the transition matrices \ucobmtrx{B}{B'} , \ucobmtrx{B'}{B''}, and \ucobmtrx{B}{B''} associated to three bases of a particular vector space. We could consider the transition from the first basis \basisfont{B} to the third basis \basisfont{B}'' as a two-step process, first converting \matrixOf{\uvec{w}}{B} to \matrixOf{\uvec{w}}{B'} by \ucobmtrx{B}{B'} \matrixOf{\uvec{w}}{B} = \matrixOf{\uvec{w}}{B'} , and then converting \matrixOf{\uvec{w}}{B'} to \matrixOf{\uvec{w}}{B''} by \ucobmtrx{B'}{B''} \matrixOf{\uvec{w}}{B'} = \matrixOf{\uvec{w}}{B''} . Substituting the first expression for \matrixOf{\uvec{w}}{B'} into the second equality, we find \ucobmtrx{B'}{B''} \ucobmtrx{B}{B'} \matrixOf{\uvec{w}}{B} = \matrixOf{\uvec{w}}{B''} , and so we expect \ucobmtrx{B'}{B''} \ucobmtrx{B}{B'} = \ucobmtrx{B}{B''} .

paragraphs.title: Reversing change of basis
paragraphs.p: Finally, we considered the relationship between transition matrices \ucobmtrx{B}{B'} and \ucobmtrx{B'}{B}. Transitioning \basisfont{B}' \to \basisfont{B} should be the reverse process of transitioning \basisfont{B} \to \basisfont{B}', and so we expect \ucobmtrx{B'}{B} = \uinvcobmtrx{B}{B'} . This relationship agrees with our expectations for no change of basis and chains of basis changes above, since if we consider basis \basisfont{B} to be both the first and third basis in a chain of basis changes, then \ucobmtrx{B'}{B} \ucobmtrx{B}{B'} = \ucobmtrx{B}{B} = I as expected if matrices \ucobmtrx{B}{B'} and \ucobmtrx{B'}{B} are inverses.

paragraphs.title: Changing to the standard basis
paragraphs.p: In , we first reminded ourselves that, relative to the standard basis \basisfont{S} of \R^n, a vector is equal to its coordinate vector. In particular, if \basisfont{B} is another basis of \R^n, then each basis vector in \basisfont{B} is equal to its own coordinate vector relative to the standard basis. So when we form a transition matrix \ucobmtrx{B}{S}, the columns of this matrix are precisely the vectors of basis \basisfont{B}, which makes \ucobmtrx{B}{S} particularly easy to produce.

paragraphs.title: Computing transition matrices using the standard basis as an intermediate
Computing transition matrices using row reduction
paragraphs.p:
We use row reduction to do just about everything, so of course we can use it to compute transition matrices! Now, computing a transition matrix using
would already be carried out by (a lot) of row reducing, as computing a coordinate vector is equivalent to solving a linear system. (See the coordinate vector examples in .) But from , we can use what we learned about computing inverses in
to develop a procedure for computing a transition matrix for \R^n by row reducing a single matrix.

In , we learned that if a matrix can be reduced to the identity by some sequence of row operations, then the exact same sequence of row operations will unreduce the identity matrix to the inverse of the original matrix. Look back at
in , which describes the pattern of . Here is that pattern again, but in abbreviated form:
\left[\begin{array}{c|c} A \amp I \end{array}\right] \qquad \rowredarrow \qquad \left[\begin{array}{c|c} E_{\ell} \dotsm E_2 E_1 A \amp E_{\ell} \dotsm E_2 E_1 I \end{array}\right] = \left[\begin{array}{c|c} I \amp \inv{A} \end{array}\right] , where the E_j are the elementary matrices associated to a sequence of operations that reduces A to I.

What if we augmented A with a matrix other than I and row reduced? Then the pattern would be
\left[\begin{array}{c|c} A \amp B \end{array}\right] \qquad \rowredarrow \qquad \left[\begin{array}{c|c} E_{\ell} \dotsm E_2 E_1 A \amp E_{\ell} \dotsm E_2 E_1 B \end{array}\right] = \left[\begin{array}{c|c} I \amp \inv{A} B \end{array}\right] . This pattern reveals that we can also carry out an inverse-times-matrix computation by row reducing! And that kind of computation is exactly what we would carry out if we used
to compute a transition matrix for \R^n.

statement.p:
To compute a transition matrix \ucobmtrx{B}{B'}, where \basisfont{B} and \basisfont{B}' are bases of \R^n, first form the transition matrices \ucobmtrx{B}{S} and \ucobmtrx{B'}{S} by writing the vectors of each of the two bases as columns in a matrix. Then augment matrix \ucobmtrx{B'}{S} with matrix \ucobmtrx{B}{S}, and row reduce until the identity matrix is obtained on the left. The matrix on the right will now be \ucobmtrx{B}{B'}.
\left[\begin{array}{c|c} \ucobmtrx{B'}{S} \amp \ucobmtrx{B}{S} \end{array}\right] \qquad\rowredarrow\qquad \left[\begin{array}{c|c} I \amp \uinvcobmtrx{B'}{S} \ucobmtrx{B}{S} \end{array}\right] = \left[\begin{array}{c|c} I \amp \ucobmtrx{B}{B'} \end{array}\right]

li.p:
Since a transition matrix \ucobmtrx{B}{S} for \R^n is formed by just writing the vectors of basis \basisfont{B} as columns in a matrix, it might be easier to remember the pattern of
if we remove some of the transition matrix notation:
\left[\begin{array}{c|c} \basisfont{B}' \amp \basisfont{B} \end{array}\right] \qquad\rowredarrow\qquad \left[\begin{array}{c|c} I \amp (\basisfont{B} \to \basisfont{B}') \end{array}\right]
(where we even could write \basisfont{S} instead of I on the left of the reduced matrix, if we wished).

Even better might be to express the pattern in words:
\left[\begin{array}{c|c} \text{New} \amp \text{Old} \end{array}\right] \qquad\rowredarrow\qquad \left[\begin{array}{c|c} I \amp (\text{Old} \to \text{New}) \end{array}\right] .

ol.li: can also be used in other vector spaces besides \R^n, particularly those that have a standard basis that can be used to easily form intermediate transition matrices to use in the row reducing procedure. We will comment again on this in , after we have seen a couple of related examples.
